message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has perineal and scrotal pain, pain during ejaculation, and dysuria, which are symptoms of chronic pelvic pain syndrome. Prostatic abscess would present with a fever and leukocytosis. Benign prostatic hyperplasia would cause urinary symptoms such as hesitancy and urgency, which are not reported here. Bladder neck cancer is an unlikely diagnosis given the absence of hematuria and abnormality on scrotal ultrasonography.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest Chronic Pelvic Pain Syndrome (CPPS), which is characterized by persistent pain in the pelvic region for longer than 3 months, and includes pain in the perineum, scrotum, and pain during ejaculation and urination. This diagnosis is supported by the laboratory findings which show no abnormalities except for a mildly tender prostate on rectal examination. Prostatic abscess and bladder neck cancer present with more severe symptoms such as fever and weight loss, and Benign Prostatic Hyperplasia typically presents with urinary hesitancy and frequency.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms, including perineal and scrotal pain, pain during ejaculation, and dysuria, suggest chronic pelvic pain syndrome. The laboratory studies and imaging also do not support the other options.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has persistent perineal and scrotal pain along with pain during ejaculation and dysuria. The laboratory studies and imaging show no abnormalities except mildly tender prostate without asymmetry or induration. These symptoms are consistent with Chronic Pelvic Pain Syndrome, which is characterized by pelvic pain, postvoid dribbling, and painful ejaculation. Prostatic abscesses usually present with fever and chills, and there is no indication of any mass to suggest benign prostatic hyperplasia or bladder neck cancer.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and laboratory findings are consistent with chronic pelvic pain syndrome. Prostatic abscess is unlikely since there is no fever or evidence of an abscess on physical examination or imaging. Benign prostatic hyperplasia usually presents with urinary symptoms such as frequency and urgency, which are absent in this case. Bladder neck cancer would present with urinary symptoms and may be associated with hematuria, which is not present in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms are consistent with chronic pelvic pain syndrome. None of the other options fit the symptoms, and the laboratory studies and tests are also not consistent with those conditions.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has persistent perineal and scrotal pain, pain during ejaculation, and dysuria, which are all symptoms of chronic pelvic pain syndrome. Prostatic abscess would cause more severe symptoms and abnormal rectal examination. Benign prostatic hyperplasia would cause urinary symptoms such as frequency and urgency, but not perineal and scrotal pain. Bladder neck cancer is a rare condition and would have more severe symptoms as well.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and laboratory studies suggest chronic pelvic pain syndrome, also known as chronic prostatitis. The mildly tender prostate and WBCs in expressed prostatic secretions support this diagnosis. Benign prostatic hyperplasia and bladder neck cancer would be unlikely given the absence of obstructive symptoms. There is no evidence to suggest a prostatic abscess.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with persistent perineal and scrotal pain, pain during ejaculation and dysuria, but with a mildly tender prostate without asymmetry or induration. Laboratory studies show no abnormalities but expressed prostatic secretions show elevated WBC count. These symptoms are indicative of chronic pelvic pain syndrome, also known as chronic prostatitis. Prostatic abscess would present with a more tender and enlarged prostate. Benign prostatic hyperplasia does not typically cause pain or dysuria. Bladder neck cancer would present with hematuria and more severe pain.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest Chronic Pelvic Pain Syndrome (CPPS), also known as chronic prostatitis. The urine culture and scrotal ultrasound are normal, ruling out Prostatic abscess and Bladder neck cancer respectively. Benign prostatic hyperplasia typically does not present with pain during ejaculation or dysuria. The mildly tender prostate seen on rectal exam is consistent with CPPS.
